1using System;
2using System.Collections.Generic;
3​
4namespace TechnicalIndicators
5{
6 /// <summary>
7 /// Linear Regression
8 /// </summary>
9 /// <remarks>
10 /// fits a straight line (y = mx + b) to the prices over the lookback period.
11 /// <list type="bullet">
12 /// <item><description>Values: The end point of the regression line (similar to LSMA).</description></item>
13 /// <item><description>Slope: The rate of change of the regression line.</description></item>
14 /// <item><description>R-Squared: The coefficient of determination (strength of fit).</description></item>
15 /// </list>
16 /// </remarks>
17 public class LinearRegression
18 {
19 public int Period { get; }
20 public List<decimal?> Values { get; } = new();
21 public List<decimal?> Slope { get; } = new();
22 public List<decimal?> RSquared { get; } = new();
23​
24 public LinearRegression(int period = 14)
25 {
26 Period = period;
27 }
28​
29 public void Calculate(IEnumerable<CandleData> candles)
30 {
31 Values.Clear(); Slope.Clear(); RSquared.Clear();
32 var candleList = new List<CandleData>(candles);
33 if (candleList.Count == 0) return;
34​
35 for (int i = 0; i < candleList.Count; i++)
36 {
37 if (i < Period - 1)
38 {
39 Values.Add(null);
40 Slope.Add(null);
41 RSquared.Add(null);
42 continue;
43 }
44​
45 decimal sumX = 0, sumY = 0, sumXY = 0, sumX2 = 0, sumY2 = 0;
46​
47 for (int j = 0; j < Period; j++)
48 {
49 decimal x = j; // Time variable (0 to Period-1)
50 decimal y = candleList[i - Period + 1 + j].Close;
51 sumX += x;
52 sumY += y;
53 sumXY += x * y;
54 sumX2 += x * x;
55 sumY2 += y * y;
56 }
57​
58 decimal n = Period;
59 decimal denominator = n * sumX2 - sumX * sumX;
60​
61 if (denominator == 0)
62 {
63 Values.Add(null); Slope.Add(null); RSquared.Add(null);
64 continue;
65 }
66​
67 decimal slope = (n * sumXY - sumX * sumY) / denominator;
68 decimal intercept = (sumY - slope * sumX) / n;
69
70 // End Value (at x = Period - 1, which corresponds to the current candle 'i')
71 decimal lrValue = intercept + slope * (Period - 1);
72​
73 // R-Squared calculation
74 decimal ssTotal = sumY2 - (sumY * sumY) / n;
75 decimal r2 = 0;
76 if (ssTotal != 0)
77 {
78 decimal ssRes = 0;
79 for (int j = 0; j < Period; j++)
80 {
81 decimal predicted = intercept + slope * j;
82 decimal actual = candleList[i - Period + 1 + j].Close;
83 ssRes += (actual - predicted) * (actual - predicted);
84 }
85 r2 = 1 - ssRes / ssTotal;
86 }
87​
88 Values.Add(lrValue);
89 Slope.Add(slope);
90 RSquared.Add(r2);
91 }
92 }
93​
94 public static List<decimal?> Calculate(IEnumerable<CandleData> candles, int period = 14)
95 {
96 var lr = new LinearRegression(period);
97 lr.Calculate(candles);
98 return lr.Values;
99 }
100 }
101}

1// =============================================================================
2// Logic Breakdown (LinearRegression)
3// =============================================================================
4//
5// This document provides a "Deep Dive" into the internal logic of the
6// Linear Regression technical indicator.
7// We explain *why* code is written this way and *how* data transforms
8// line-by-line, targeting programming beginners.
9//
10// [Core Concepts]
11//
12// 1. What is This Indicator?
13// [What] A comprehensive linear regression tool that outputs THREE values:
14// - Values: The predicted price (regression line endpoint)
15// - Slope: The trend direction/strength
16// - RSquared: How well the line fits the data (0 to 1)
17//
18// 2. R-Squared (Coefficient of Determination)
19// [Formula]
20// R² = 1 - (SS_res / SS_tot)
21//
22// SS_tot = Σ(y - mean)² (Total variance in the data)
23// SS_res = Σ(y - predicted)² (Residual/unexplained variance)
24//
25// [Interpretation]
26// R² ≈ 1 → Line explains most of the price movement (strong trend)
27// R² ≈ 0 → Line doesn't explain the data (no linear relationship)
28//
29// [Visual: High vs Low R²]
30//
31// High R² (≈ 0.9): Low R² (≈ 0.2):
32// @ @ @
33// @ @
34// @ @ @
35// @ @ @
36// ─────────── (line) ───────────
37// Data closely follows line Data scattered around line
38//
39// 3. Use Cases
40// - Compare RSquared across different timeframes
41// - Filter trades: Only trade when R² > threshold (e.g., 0.8)
42// - Combine Slope and R² for trend strength confirmation
43//
44// =============================================================================
45​
46using System;
47using System.Collections.Generic;
48​
49namespace TechnicalIndicators
50{
51 // =============================================================================
52 // Logic Explanation: OHLCV Data Container
53 // =============================================================================
54 public readonly record struct CandleData(
55 DateTime Timestamp,
56 decimal Open,
57 decimal High,
58 decimal Low,
59 decimal Close,
60 long Volume
61 );
62​
63 // =============================================================================
64 // Logic Explanation: LinearRegression Class
65 // =============================================================================
66 public class LinearRegression
67 {
68 // -------------------------------------------------------------
69 // Logic Explanation: Configuration & Outputs
70 //
71 // [Why Three Lists?]
72 // Each output serves a different purpose:
73 // - Values: For trend following (like an MA)
74 // - Slope: For momentum/direction analysis
75 // - RSquared: For trend quality filtering
76 // -------------------------------------------------------------
77 public int Period { get; }
78 public List<decimal?> Values { get; } = new();
79 public List<decimal?> Slope { get; } = new();
80 public List<decimal?> RSquared { get; } = new();
81​
82 // =============================================================================
83 // Logic Explanation: Constructor
84 // =============================================================================
85 public LinearRegression(int period = 14)
86 {
87 if (period <= 0)
88 throw new ArgumentOutOfRangeException(nameof(period), "Period must be greater than 0");
89
90 Period = period;
91 }
92​
93 // =============================================================================
94 // Logic Explanation: Main Calculation Method
95 // =============================================================================
96 public void Calculate(IEnumerable<CandleData> candles)
97 {
98 // -------------------------------------------------------------
99 // Step 1: Cleanup
100 // -------------------------------------------------------------
101 Values.Clear();
102 Slope.Clear();
103 RSquared.Clear();
104​
105 var candleList = new List<CandleData>(candles);
106 if (candleList.Count == 0) return;
107​
108 // -------------------------------------------------------------
109 // Step 2: Main Loop
110 // -------------------------------------------------------------
111 for (int i = 0; i < candleList.Count; i++)
112 {
113 // [Check] Need 'Period' bars
114 if (i < Period - 1)
115 {
116 Values.Add(null);
117 Slope.Add(null);
118 RSquared.Add(null);
119 continue;
120 }
121​
122 // -------------------------------------------------------------
123 // Step 3: Calculate Summations
124 //
125 // [Additional] We also need ΣY² for R² calculation.
126 // -------------------------------------------------------------
127 decimal sumX = 0, sumY = 0, sumXY = 0, sumX2 = 0, sumY2 = 0;
128​
129 for (int j = 0; j < Period; j++)
130 {
131 decimal x = j;
132 decimal y = candleList[i - Period + 1 + j].Close;
133​
134 sumX += x;
135 sumY += y;
136 sumXY += x * y;
137 sumX2 += x * x;
138 sumY2 += y * y;
139 }
140​
141 // -------------------------------------------------------------
142 // Step 4: Calculate Slope and Intercept
143 // -------------------------------------------------------------
144 decimal n = Period;
145 decimal denominator = n * sumX2 - sumX * sumX;
146​
147 if (denominator == 0)
148 {
149 Values.Add(null);
150 Slope.Add(null);
151 RSquared.Add(null);
152 continue;
153 }
154​
155 decimal slope = (n * sumXY - sumX * sumY) / denominator;
156 decimal intercept = (sumY - slope * sumX) / n;
157​
158 // -------------------------------------------------------------
159 // Step 5: Calculate Regression Value (Endpoint)
160 //
161 // [Note] Using (Period - 1) because X = 0, 1, ..., Period-1
162 // The last X value in the window is Period - 1.
163 // -------------------------------------------------------------
164 decimal lrValue = intercept + slope * (Period - 1);
165​
166 // -------------------------------------------------------------
167 // Step 6: Calculate R-Squared
168 //
169 // [Formula]
170 // SS_tot = ΣY² - (ΣY)²/n (Total Sum of Squares)
171 // SS_res = Σ(actual - predicted)² (Residual Sum of Squares)
172 // R² = 1 - SS_res / SS_tot
173 //
174 // [Visual: R² Calculation]
175 //
176 // For each point j in window:
177 // predicted[j] = intercept + slope × j
178 // residual[j] = actual[j] - predicted[j]
179 // SS_res += residual[j]²
180 // -------------------------------------------------------------
181 decimal ssTotal = sumY2 - (sumY * sumY) / n;
182 decimal r2 = 0;
183​
184 if (ssTotal != 0)
185 {
186 decimal ssRes = 0;
187​
188 for (int j = 0; j < Period; j++)
189 {
190 decimal predicted = intercept + slope * j;
191 decimal actual = candleList[i - Period + 1 + j].Close;
192 decimal residual = actual - predicted;
193 ssRes += residual * residual;
194 }
195​
196 r2 = 1 - ssRes / ssTotal;
197 }
198​
199 Values.Add(lrValue);
200 Slope.Add(slope);
201 RSquared.Add(r2);
202 }
203 }
204​
205 // =============================================================================
206 // Logic Explanation: Static Convenience Wrapper
207 //
208 // [IPO Block]
209 // Input: IEnumerable<CandleData>, int period
210 // Process: Creates instance, runs Calculate()
211 // Output: List of regression values (Values only)
212 //
213 // [Note] Static method only returns Values.
214 // For Slope and RSquared, use instance method.
215 // =============================================================================
216 public static List<decimal?> Calculate(IEnumerable<CandleData> candles, int period = 14)
217 {
218 var lr = new LinearRegression(period);
219 lr.Calculate(candles);
220 return lr.Values;
221 }
222 }
223}

1# =============================================================================
2# Logic Breakdown (Linear Regression)
3# =============================================================================
4#
5# This document provides a "Deep Dive" into the internal logic of the
6# Linear Regression Indicator. We explain *why* code is written this way
7# and *how* data transforms line-by-line, targeting programming beginners.
8#
9# [Core Concepts]
10# 1. Statistical Fitting (Least Squares)
11# We fit a straight line (y = mx + b) through the N most recent prices.
12# - "y" is Price.
13# - "x" is Time.
14# The line is chosen to minimize the "Sum of Squared Errors" (Vertical distances).
15#
16# 2. The 3 Outputs
17# - Forecast (Price): Where the line ends *today*. (Usually differs from actual price).
18# - Slope (Trend): How steep is the line? (High = Strong Trend).
19# - R-Squared (Confidence): How well does the line fit the dots?
20# (1.0 = Perfect Fit, 0.0 = Random Noise).
21#
22# 3. Use Case
23# Traders use "Forecast" to see the "Mean value" relative to trend.
24# Traders use "Slope" to filter trade direction.
25# Traders use "R-Squared" to avoid trading during sideways chop.
26#
27# =============================================================================
28​
29# -------------------------------------------------------------
30# Type-Level Explanation: LinearRegression (class)
31#
32# [Why] Encapsulates multi-metric regression analysis.
33# [What] A statistical toolkit for trend analysis.
34# [How] Performs a linear regression (least squares fit) on prices over a lookback period to determine the current trend value, slope, and strength (R-squared).
35# [Visual]
36# / (Line)
37# ./. (Dots = Prices)
38# ./
39# /
40# [Who] Quants, Statistical Arbitrageurs.
41# [Where] Heap.
42# -------------------------------------------------------------
43class LinearRegression:
44​
45 # -------------------------------------------------------------
46 # Logic Explanation: Indicator Configuration (Public Properties)
47 #
48 # [Why]
49 # Standard configuration: How far back to look?
50 # -------------------------------------------------------------
51​
52 # -------------------------------------------------------------
53 # Constructor: __init__
54 #
55 # [Input]
56 # - period: int (Window size)
57 #
58 # [Why]
59 # Initialize implementation constants.
60 # -------------------------------------------------------------
61 def __init__(self, period=14):
62
63 # -------------------------------------------------------------
64 # Logic Step 1: Validation
65 # -------------------------------------------------------------
66 if period <= 1:
67 raise ValueError(f"Period must be greater than 1. Received: {period}")
68​
69 self.period = period
70
71 # Output Buffers
72 self.values = [] # The Forecasted Price (End Point)
73 self.slope = [] # The Trend Steepness
74 self.r_squared = [] # The Fit Quality (Coefficient of Determination)
75​
76​
77 # =============================================================================
78 # IPO: calculate
79 # =============================================================================
80 #
81 # [Input]
82 # - candles: list[dict] (Must have 'close')
83 #
84 # [Process]
85 # 1. Iterate through data with a sliding window.
86 # 2. Compute Sums needed for Regression (X, Y, XY, X^2, Y^2).
87 # 3. Solve for Slope (m) and Intercept (b).
88 # 4. Compute Forecast = m * CurrentX + b.
89 # 5. Compute R-Squared from Sums and Residuals.
90 #
91 # [Output]
92 # - None (populates 3 lists)
93 # =============================================================================
94 def calculate(self, candles):
95
96 # -------------------------------------------------------------
97 # Logic Step 1: Reset
98 # -------------------------------------------------------------
99 self.values.clear()
100 self.slope.clear()
101 self.r_squared.clear()
102
103 count = len(candles)
104 if count == 0:
105 return
106​
107 # -------------------------------------------------------------
108 # Logic Step 2: Main Loop
109 #
110 # [Why]
111 # Re-calculate regression statistics for every new bar.
112 # -------------------------------------------------------------
113 for i in range(count):
114
115 # -------------------------------------------------------------
116 # Logic Step 2.1: Insufficient Data
117 # -------------------------------------------------------------
118 if i < self.period - 1:
119 self.values.append(None)
120 self.slope.append(None)
121 self.r_squared.append(None)
122 continue
123​
124 # -------------------------------------------------------------
125 # Logic Step 2.2: Accumulate Statistics (O(N^2))
126 #
127 # [What] We need 5 sums to solve everything:
128 # SumX, SumY, SumXY, SumX^2, SumY^2
129 # -------------------------------------------------------------
130 sum_x = 0.0
131 sum_y = 0.0
132 sum_xy = 0.0
133 sum_sq_x = 0.0
134 sum_sq_y = 0.0
135
136 # Iterate window [i - period + 1 ... i]
137 for j in range(self.period):
138 # X: 0 to N-1 (Time)
139 x = j
140
141 # Y: Price
142 idx = i - self.period + 1 + j
143 y = candles[idx]['close']
144
145 sum_x += x
146 sum_y += y
147 sum_xy += (x * y)
148 sum_sq_x += (x * x)
149 sum_sq_y += (y * y)
150​
151 # -------------------------------------------------------------
152 # Logic Step 2.3: Solve Linear Equation
153 #
154 # [Formula]
155 # m = (N*SumXY - SumX*SumY) / Denom
156 # Denom = N*SumX2 - SumX^2
157 # b = (SumY - m*SumX) / N
158 # -------------------------------------------------------------
159 n = self.period
160 numerator = (n * sum_xy) - (sum_x * sum_y)
161 denominator = (n * sum_sq_x) - (sum_x * sum_x)
162
163 # Guard against flat lines/div 0
164 if denominator == 0:
165 self.values.append(None)
166 self.slope.append(None)
167 self.r_squared.append(None)
168 continue
169
170 slope = numerator / denominator
171 intercept = (sum_y - (slope * sum_x)) / n
172​
173 # -------------------------------------------------------------
174 # Logic Step 2.4: Forecast Value (Endpoint)
175 #
176 # [Why] What is the line's value at the current bar (Index N-1)?
177 # -------------------------------------------------------------
178 current_x = self.period - 1
179 forecast = intercept + (slope * current_x)
180
181 # -------------------------------------------------------------
182 # Logic Step 2.5: Calculate R-Squared (Fit Quality)
183 #
184 # [Formula]
185 # R2 = 1 - (SS_res / SS_tot)
186 # SS_tot = Sum((y - mean_y)^2)
187 # SS_res = Sum((y - predicted)^2)
188 # -------------------------------------------------------------
189
190 # A. Total Sum of Squares (Variance from Mean)
191 # Optimized Formula: SumY2 - (SumY^2)/N
192 ss_total = sum_sq_y - ((sum_y * sum_y) / n)
193
194 r2 = 0.0
195 if ss_total != 0:
196 # B. Residual Sum of Squares (Variance from Line)
197 # Must re-iterate to sum errors
198 ss_res = 0.0
199 for j in range(self.period):
200 x = j
201 actual_y = candles[i - self.period + 1 + j]['close']
202 predicted_y = intercept + (slope * x)
203
204 error = actual_y - predicted_y
205 ss_res += (error * error)
206
207 r2 = 1.0 - (ss_res / ss_total)
208​
209 # -------------------------------------------------------------
210 # Logic Step 2.6: Store Results
211 # -------------------------------------------------------------
212 self.values.append(forecast)
213 self.slope.append(slope)
214 self.r_squared.append(r2)
215​
216​
217# =============================================================================
218# Functional Wrapper (Procedural Interface)
219# =============================================================================
220def calculate(candles, period=14):
221 """
222 Computes Linear Regression Forecast, Slope, and R-Squared.
223 """
224 # 1. Instantiation
225 instance = LinearRegression(period)
226
227 # 2. Execution
228 instance.calculate(candles)
229
230 # 3. Extraction
231 return instance.values, instance.slope, instance.r_squared
